field.name: summary
field.value: Add real security to authentication process

field.name: description
field.value:
right now, our security consists of the following: a cookie is transmitted with the user's id, which indicates which user we are talking to. If, on the user table, that user is marked as "logged in", they are authenticated. Also, we only allow https connections.
Possible threats: # If a user is logged in and another user sends us a cookie with that user's id, then they get access.
authentication design considerations: must be very fast. No slow lookups at any point. should be flexible - if we need to alter crypto keys, or whatever, it should be doable easily with minimal harm. should be secure. Consider: man in the middle attacks, collecting cookies, replay attacks, etc.
Suggested design: *Have a private key on server side that decrypts the cookie. *The cookie should be information-opaque. That is, no attacker should be able to glean anything from the cookie * The cookie should be unencrypted quickly. It doesn't need to be very secure, it just has to be fast. That's because one of our other considerations is that these cookies will expire and be unusable after a short time. * The cookie should expire after a short time, easily configurable. * the expiration should be clean and thorough. By this I mean it should expire first on the client, so the browser won't even send it, and shortly after (like by milliseconds) by the server. Further, there should be code that appears on the client indicating that time is nearly up, along with a page refresh when it does expire. * If the user is active, then the timeout should constantly be reset. * We should track the user's ip along with the cookie, so we know we're getting hoodwinked if we see that cookie coming from somewhere else. * a timestamp should get encoded into the cookie to avoid replay attacks.
In summary: with a private key, we'll encrypt the time the cookie is created, along with a constantly-shifting int value that points to the user in question. The cookie will require secure connection to be sent, and will be registered for our domain only. It will be a session cookie, so that it disappears from the user's browser when they close it. (discuss). The server will need a separate process or thread to handle the timeout concept.

comment.author: byron
comment.text: Looking further, I think it makes sense to do this: store the user id, a timestamp, and the ip for the client as a pipe-delimited (|) string, and encrypt it with AES, and send that as the cookie. When we receive a cookie, we'll decrypt and get those values. If the ip has changed, we'll redirect to get authenticated again and therefore will create a new cookie with the new ip. We'll check the timestamp too - when we create the cookie we'll make a note of when we did that, and we'll store that value in the database and the cookie itself. The timestamp provides multiple capabilities, but the primary one I am thinking of here is that it acts as a salt - otherwise, we would always be encrypting the ip and username to be the same value, and if anyone got that value they could use it. With the timestamp in it, that is prevented to a degree. The encrypted value will always be changing.

comment.author: byron
comment.text: So based on what we've discussed so far: When the user correctly authenticates, we will get the current datetime, their ip, and their user_id, and encrypt that with AES. We will store that datetime into the last_logged_in field on the user table. We will hand the cookie to the user. When we get a cookie from a user, we will decrypt it. If we cannot decrypt it, we will redirect that user to re-authenticate. If we decrypt properly, we will verify the timestamp and the ip for that user_id. If anything is off, we will redirect them to re-authenticate. At this point, the user is authenticated.

This is the cancel-active-requestoffer capability. It can be done by either the owner of the requestoffer or the servicer, with the same choices and outcomes available.
For the owner: Why would they cancel? * they want someone else to service it, or they don't trust the current servicer * the current servicer is doing a terrible job * the need has disappeared while in the middle of getting serviced * they are unable to continue providing the need
For the servicer: Why would they cancel? * the transaction is going poorly * they don't think they'll get anything out of it - points, rank, etc. * they are unable to continue servicing it
If the owner clicks cancel, they should have the ability to choose thumbs-up / thumbs-down for servicer.
If the servicer clicks cancel, they should have the ability to choose thumbs-up/thumbs-down for the owner.
Then, the requestoffer goes to "open" state, which allows deletion.

comment.author: byron
comment.text:
Here's an interesting thing: First 1000 people (100? 10?) get 3 favor points automatically. This acts as an incentive to join.
As time goes on, and more people join, we start applying a rule where if you are new, you start at 0 and you have to start by earning a point, then you are allowed to request a favor, but you can only create one. Then you have to handle a favor again, and you have to go positive, etc, etc. The details of the algorithm can be set up later, but the gist is that we gradually build up trust in an individual that they are part of this thing rather than cheaters or UM's.
Rank becomes a big deal in this thing. It's tied to how many thumbs up / thumbs down, but also how many variety - if it's just two people exclusively doing business with each other, it's harder to tell the validity of their opinions on each other and whether those points are *earned*.

comment.author: byron
comment.text: One other consideration, and this has been covered in part before: The initial people to the system, they will receive less careful vetting, they are the luckier ones. Gradually, the amount of trust that must be earned off the bat will increase, until the final stage where a new user will need to fulfill several favors by several people before they are even allowed to create a favor request. Eventually they will move to a place of joining the community as a full-fledged member. At that point, trust will be maintained by a certain transparency in rankings and history.

comment.author: byron
comment.text: The early birds to the system will have it easy. The later entrants will have to fight hard to earn their membership. So as far as gaming the system, it won't be possible to create dozens of accounts to create favor requests to make one user rich - it won't be worth their while, they will have to do so much for the community at that point, they will have contributed more than they took.

More to the point, if I am a sneaky evil person, I can just wait 6 months for my rankings to clear, then start doing some stuff and get like 100% ranking, then use that for nefarious ends. Better to have a more sophisticated system that takes more variables into account: *When you start, you're unknown - 0 ranking *It's possible to go negative, which means you are actively badly ranked, not merely unknown. *There is a 6 month rolling window which causes rankings outside of that 6 months to disappear from whatever calculation we use for rank *getting good rankings is slower than getting bad rankings. On the other hand, if we do this by accepting an email, we have to verify that the email is valid - which it can be difficult to do. Sure, with some of the biggies like hotmail and yahoo and gmail you have some certificate stuff you can do, but really in the end it's pretty easy to spoof it. Whereas, if we send an email to some account using TLS encryption, and they click a link from that email to verify, it seems much more sure everything's legit.
Maybe there *is* a reason why every website does it this way. Ha.

field.name: description
field.value:
Right now, we just present fields to the user and take values as strings. That will cause a lot of locations to be indecipherable. Instead, we should do this: * they first go to a screen where they select their country. * they then move to a new screen where they select their postal code. They have the option to go back and choose a different country. * selecting a postal code is a matter of using the dropdown. It may be possible to apply some simple javascript to make this an autocomplete. * each postal code will have information associated with it, in string form. things like place names, states, cities. * once they are happy with their choice, they click next and we show them the fields for address along with their country, city, state, and postal code. * a user location entry will consist of an id that goes to a country / postal code pair. Address is not necessary.
benefits: people's locations are much likelier to be useable for distance calculations. people are less likely to insert junk data less data stored - all those strings for locations will go away, leaving just id's. users who need to be more specific on their location can just include it in the communication to their handler.

comment.author: byron
comment.text:
I've gone through multiple permutations on this one. The previous techniques I had: * show an initial page asking if they have a location, then taking them to the appropriate page - if they needed a location, there would be extra fields for address and such. * have a button that expanded out to show the address fields. Whether or not the user clicked the button, there had to be *some* location information for the system to associate a location to a favor
There are positives and negatives to the way I am doing it: negatives: * a user has to decide at the onset whether to go one way or the other. They cannot start writing up the favor and then decide it needs a location - they would have to store their text somewhere and restart with a location-based favor. * there is more than one button for favor - a user has to think to themselves which one to click. * the possibility of having to go through more pages, more thrashing, to get things done.
positives: * it's simple. It doesn't require JavaScript at all. Since the whole system moves crazy fast, clicking through shouldn't hamper them at all.
considerations: * the edge cases and use cases for selecting a location are a little trickier than you might think at first. First, you have to select a country, because the postal codes are only unique within a given country. Then they enter their postal code. The set of data for postal codes is about 2 megabytes per country. So if the user enters a country of "USA" and postal code 2016, the system will search for 2016 and send every possible postal code that could match. Like, 20165, or 12016. If they type "1" as postal code, xenos will send dozens or hundreds of possible matches for them to choose amongst. But it's all pretty snappy. If the user enters something that matches nothing, the system says so. This all leads up to this statement: to do that on one page, cleanly, with excellent UX/UI, will require a lot of Javascript and AJAX, something I am trying hard to avoid. Yes, it's not perfect, but it's fast, works well, and will work on basically every device in the world because it doesn't rely on JavaScript for funtioning. I like using JavaScript for some niceties, little flourishes that aren't necessary but make things sweeter. I hesitate using it for base, essential functionality.

comment.author: byron
comment.text:
The convention you describe, where users return to a page with a dialog or banner (usually at the top) indicating what just happened, is a very common one. I agree that it is very common, and considered the typical experience. However, I believe this is one of those cases where one could argue about the merits of the approach.
In that user experience, a user is looking at a typical page, like the dashboard, and is then expected to notice there is something different. I believe that people are not really very good at the game of "find what is different about this page". At the very least, I would argue that looking at a typical page, people see what they expect to see and often don't see unexpected stuff. That part of human nature - to not see unexpected stuff - is pretty well documented.
That's why I chose to do it the way I did. If you do something in this system, you'll go to a page that tells you so, and is the only thing to see on that page. The whole system moves damn fast, so clicking on the dashboard button under it will take you back home instantly. But for all those people who don't see it or go looking for the unexpected alert, this is a way to make things clearer.

comment.author: byron
comment.text:
well..ok this brings up a few things: * Regarding auto-complete: I didn't want to give people the ability to search users, to avoid some edge cases like anti-social people spamming others and so on. If you want someone in your group, you need their exact username, either because you've seen them before or they told you in real life what their username is. The group system is very discreet - you won't even know someone is in a group unless you share that group with them. This also makes it more secure - you can rest easy knowing the info in your group description is only seen by a select few that the group owner had to intentionally invite. * Regarding accepting emails and getting an invite to the app - anonymity is a priority in the system. If there was an invite system using emails like that, it could act to subvert that purpose. If, after someone is a member, they wish to add their email, I could see adding a feature to record that - maybe for sending notices or whatnot. But I wouldn't want to make it a prominent way of being invited into the system.
Right now, users joining the system and users joining groups are intentionally two separate things. The expected use case is: alice says to bob, "hey, join me at zenia", bob says ok. alice sends an invite, bob joins. bob emails alice his username. alice invites that username to her group.
